intro: Ipomoea huillensis, commonly known as the Huillén morning glory, is a climbing vine native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Convolvulaceae family and is characterized by its heart-shaped leaves and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from white to purple. The plant produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small, smooth seeds. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in shaded or semi-shaded environments. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and natural habitats.
